Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a crude horse standing and looking ahead. Riding gear is depicted with painted (black) detail. A hole is drilled through the muzzle of the horse. Mould-made in a two piece mould, with the moulding lines reworked with a flat tool. Hollow. Red slip and painted. Red-brown Nile silt with grey core and abundant mica, organics, quartz and white inclusions. Complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of Roman terracotta figures in the Fitzwilliam Museum are in the same style (Horse E.150.1914, E.106.1914, rider E.108.1914 and sothic dog E.149.1914). Close to 2nd to 3rd century AD parallel from 'Antinoopolis' with same hole drilled through the bit of the horses (Dunand 1990, no. 840) and Roman Memphis example (Petrie Museum UC48048). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.276) (Phase 3)
